text: good afternoon welcome back from lunch uh hopefully all didn't eat too much so
you don't fall asleep but we'll we'll keep it exciting and interesting uh thanks for coming to the the Earth on AWS session uh we did one of these last
year uh that was really really well received and so we we wanted to come back and and raise the bar a little bit
so uh we're really really happy to have Kevin Murphy here from NASA to talk about what NASA is doing to uh encourage
earth science research in the cloud so my name is Jed sunwall I run the open data program at Amazon web services and
what our program does is Works to explore ways to share large scale data in the cloud and help our customers
whether they're government agencies or research institutions that have large volumes of data that they want to share external to their organization uh to
figure out how to do that in the cloud so before Kevin comes on stage I just want to talk a little bit about our
program and some of the experiments that we've done uh so far so first of all you know the question we we do get from time
to time is why does AWS have an open data program why do we care about open data and the the short answer is that we
care about open data because our customers really care about open data we have a lot of customers whether they're
researchers or entrepreneurs or Enterprises that they rely on government data or otherwise publicly shared data
for their missions um their products would not exist without the availability of of of open data and so what what we
get to talk to a lot of government uh customers who have data that they want to share is that when they make their data available on AWS
they're able to make it available to this large and growing group of users who who really want to benefit from the
data and one of the benefits of the cloud is that it makes it a lot easier for people to work with data without
having to acquire it and download it themselves so there's a a book that I that I highly recommend it's a very very
quick read it's called Data driven it it was written by DJ patile who was the chief data scientist of the United
States in the previous administration and then Hillary Mason who's a data scientist they got together and wrote this book it's actually free on the
Kindle so uh I I make no money if anybody downloads it um there's no
commissions on this one but they they finally wrote down this figure that gets thrown around a lot which is that 80% of
a data scientist's work is spent just preparing data for analysis and whenever
I talk to people about this and and share this figure everybody agrees and but if anything when you're talking
about working with with Earth observation data or these like really heavy data sets that are terabyte or paby scale data sets 80% is probably too
isn't is too generous right it probably takes more time than that to to get those data into a place where they can
be worked with and we actually have a term for this kind of thing at AWS uh it's it's undifferentiated heavy lifting
we talk about this all the time and we think about undifferentiated heavy lifting in terms of what are the things that our customers have to do what are
the chores that they have to go through to before they can actually start doing the work that differentiates them and
that is actually related to their mission uh so one way that we we tend to think about what we do when we open up
data on on the cloud is that we can make free data cheaper right so there's a lot
of data that's free and the government makes it available for free but it's just really expensive to get because it takes a lot of time uh to acquire or you
know previously if you wanted to work with 10 terabytes of data you needed to have 10 terabytes of your own storage to
work with it and so when data is available in the cloud that's no longer the case uh we did a a project over the
past few years with Noah where we made a lot of radar data available in the cloud and one of the really interesting
findings from this experiment was that Noah looked at the usage patterns of the data before and after the data was
available in the cloud and what you can see in this graph is about four years of data it's actually a period of January
to July from 2013 to 2016 and what you're seeing is access of
NEX R radar data from Noah's data centers and in 2014 2015 it was about
150 terabytes during that period of time after the data was made available on AWS
usage skyrocketed 2.3% or 2.3 times and what we saw there and then
also most of the data actually just came out of of S3 after they started making the data available on on Amazon S3 and
what this tells us is that there was a lot of latent research waiting to be done there's a lot of work that people wanted to do with this data but they
weren't doing it because it was just hard for them to get and when we made it easier for them to access the data and
we made it possible for them to process the data in the cloud it unlocked a lot of usage and one surprising example of
usage that we saw out of this was from a researcher at the University of Oklahoma who studies radar data to uh evaluate
bird migration patterns and so I'm actually I'm going to go back and like replay this this thing so these are
birds uh migrating on on a radar scan so they actually have sort of a signature
ring pattern that gets created as the as a flock Rises and what this researcher at the University of Oklahoma was was
trying to do was to find correlation or relationships between uh weather events or things like
droughts floods and other you know different seasonal changes and bird migration patterns and he knew that the data existed in this Noah radar data but
it was just really hard for him to get it uh acquiring the data from Noah could take weeks uh for him to ship discs back
and forth and find out who could get get him the data and now that the data is available on AWS it's just a matter of seconds for him to make a request for
the data that he wanted and so that was very unexpected application of this data that we that would had been locked up before and that is now
possible uh and then another another research thing that we've done is with lanat on AWS where we started making
lanat satellite imagery available on the cloud uh for anybody to use in the cloud
and what's been exciting about about the lanat data has been that we were we were able to work with a lot of customers who
were really passionate about lanat they had really exciting things that they wanted to do with lanat data but it was hard for them to get so we talked to
them about how they actually acquire lanet data and um actually I'm going to go back a slide again so landside data
is provided in multiple files per scene like if you want to look at a part of the planet you have to landside data
provides you with visible imagery uh so data based on visible light so you can
you know just look at like a normal picture of that part of the planet but they also provide infed data thermal data and other things that people can
use and typically when you get landet data uh from from a government server
you get it in a tar archive so you just get one object per scene so you get all the visible data you get all the infrared data and everything else
we talked to a lot of people though we realized not everybody wants all of that data each time and so they end up
spending a lot a lot of time downloading data that they don't even use they just download it they unpack that tar archive
and they throw away 60 70% of what they got so what we do with L out NWS is that
we get those tar archives from USGS we use ec2 and Lambda we have a workflow
that we work on with with Planet Labs uh that runs this with us and then separate all the the different files into
separate files and make those available S3 and what this does it allows people to query precisely the data that they
want when they want it so they don't actually have to acquire or download any data that that they don't need and the
the response has been really great we've we've logged over a billion requests for this data uh within the first year that
that we launched it and and the reaction to this has been really really spectacular uh and but what we're really
excited about when we do these things is when we can find evidence of people really saving time and developing new
products because the data is available in this way so I'll explain to you what this what this graph is showing you this is from a
guy uh named Drew Ballinger who actually works across the street from the convention center uh but he he came up
with this graph showing off the time required for him to work with lanat Data before and after uh lanat on AWS so
those points that are on the the left hand side that are a little bit higher that's how long it would take him to process a lat scene previously just
because of the just the time required to down download the the data and unpack it and it's somewhere about 37 25 seconds
400 seconds per scene that he was accessing and analyzing once the data was made available on was made available
available on AWS that time per scene analysis dropped down about 25 30 40
seconds and there are about 990,000 points on this graph uh and so I did the math and what you're seeing here is
about 250 days of time saved for one researcher so that's 250 days of time
back because he didn't have to spend time downloading data uh that he could actually work on the analysis and
finding insights from the data and this is the kind of stuff that we love to see and shows us that there really is a lot of value to making data available in a
cloud environment so those are some of the experiments that we've done uh it's a really fun project you know that we
